citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
A routine animal welfare inspection was attempted on 11/27/2023 at 2:22 pm. However, the licensee refused to allow the
APHIS inspector to conduct the inspection, despite there being three other responsible employees present in addition to
himself. I requested for someone to accompany me on the tour that was 18 years of age or older, however the licensee
stated he did not have anyone available, and it was an inconvenient time. I informed him of the consequences of the
refusal, to which he debated with me about the unfairness of the situation and made many accusatory statements,
including that I was inspecting too frequently. I explained to him the nature of past non-compliances and the inspection
frequency, among other things in response to what he mentioned. He continued to debate with me some more and
threatened to get rid of his license. I reminded him that it is his right, as well as familiarizing himself with the activities and
species which fall under our purview by reviewing the AWA/Blue book. I also explained what he would need to do to
discontinue his license with us. Once I saw the matter was not being resolved, and he was not providing anyone to
accompany me on an inspection, I told him I would leave and document the visit as a refusal; to which he agreed and said
that would be best. Refusal to allow inspection is a serious violation of the Animal Welfare Act. Each dealer, exhibitor,
intermediate handler or carrier, shall, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept
by the Act and the regulations in this part, and to inspect and photograph the facilities, property and animals, as the
APHIS officials consider necessary to enforce the provisions of the Act, the regulations and the standards in this
subchapter.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
